H0.text: Fungi were long considered part of the plant kingdom because of obvious similarities; both are immobile, have cell walls, and grow in soil.

H1.text: Mosses were long considered part of the plant kingdom because of obvious similarities; both are immobile, have cell walls, and grow in soil.

H2.text: Coral was long considered part of the plant kingdom because both coral and plants are immobile, have cell walls, and grow in soil.

H3.text: Bacteria were long considered part of the plant kingdom because of obvious similarities; both are immobile, have cell walls, and grow in soil.

A4.text: Before the introduction of molecular methods for phylogenetic analysis, taxonomists considered fungi to be members of the plant kingdom because of similarities in lifestyle: both fungi and plants are mainly immobile, and have similarities in general morphology and growth habit.

A5.text: The bacteria were also included in fungi in some classifications, as the group Schizomycetes.
